text.p: The Australian wheat market has been "sick across the board" in reaction to the increased estimated of the crop by the Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics (ABARE) and a cut in the Australian Wheat Board's (AWB) estimate of pool returns, the AWB said.
ABARE's crop estimate was increased by 900,000 tonnes to 20.9 million tonnes while the estimate of pool returns was cut by A$5.00 a tonne, the AWB noted in its weekly report.
Milling wheat prices were most affected, dropping by as much as A$13.00 a tonne in New South Wales (NSW) and up to A$8.00 a tonne elsewhere last week, the AWB said.
Feed grain prices dropped dropped by A$5.00 or A$6.00 a tonne in Queensland but barley held firm in NSW, Victoria and South Australia (SA), it said.
Values for chick peas dropped in Queensland but were steady elsewhere. Lupins rose by A$5.00 a tonne in SA and the delivered Melbourne quiote for canola rose by A$4.00 a tonne.
The AWB's wheat indicator price delivered Newcastle fell by A$8.00 a tonne to A$136.75 over the past week. The indicator price for Durum fell by A$5.00 a tonne to A$190.00 a tonne.
The AWB said its next revision for the Australian wheat crop was expected on November 1.
Significant tenders were called during the week by Egypt, Pakistan and Algeria.
Egyptian specifications call for Australian or French wheat, while Pakistan was calling for U.S. wheat on credit and Algeria is calling for French or Argentine wheat, it said.

Argentina continued to set the price in the global market at A$15.00 to A$20.00 a tonne less than other exporters, the AWB said. EU officials moved during the week to double the level of subsidy offered on wheat exports to about A$20.00 a tonne, bringing another complaint from the U.S.
The EU subsidy on feed barley continues at A$41.00 a tonne.
